title: Paris 2024: The anti-Olympic movement struggles to rally
summary: Activist groups such as Soulèvements de la Terre, Extinction Rebellion and Saccage 2024 admit that the event is perhaps too big for them to successfully protest.

title: Paris 2024: How will airports cope with the challenge of the Olympic and Paralympic Games?
summary: While international airport operator ADP Group doesn't expect a surge in overall travelers during the event, the company will have to manage 64,000 accredited guests, as well as thousands of non-standard baggage items.

title: A short history of artificial intelligence in video games, from 'Pac-Man' to 'Dragon's Dogma 2'
summary: The unveiling of Ubisoft's new generative AI project prototype in March has fueled speculation about using generative intelligence to bring non-player characters to life. Is this a new milestone in the evolving partnership between video games and AI?

title: Women take center stage in Mexico's televised presidential debate
summary: The debate between former Mexico City mayor Claudia Sheinbaum and right-wing senator Xochitl Galvez on Sunday did not change the balance of power, with Sheinbaum, seen as President Lopez Obrador's heir, likely to win the June 2 election.

title: Peter Higgs, Nobel-winning physicist who proposed existence of 'God particle', dies at 94
summary: The University of Edinburgh said he died on Monday "peacefully at home following a short illness." The physicist won the 2013 Nobel Prize in Physics for his work that helped explain how matter formed after the Big Bang.

title: Champions League: Real Madrid and Man City draw in 6-goal thriller, Arsenal snatch last-minute tie with Bayern
summary: Real Madrid and Manchester City tied 3-3 in a fast-paced quarterfinal first leg, with three early goals and three more in the second half. Arsenal and Bayern Munich also drew 2-2, with Leandro Trossard equalizing late after Harry Kane's penalty.

title: Arizona can enforce 1864 law criminalizing nearly all abortions, court says
summary: The ruling permits doctors or others to be prosecuted for performing an abortion at any time unless the mother's life is in danger, with no exceptions for rape or incest.

title: Champions League: Security 'considerably' reinforced at stadiums following IS threat
summary: The quarterfinal matches in Paris, Madrid and London will all go ahead despite the terror threats.

title: Former ballerinas, victims of educational abuse by teachers, break their silence
summary: Two former dancers from the Paris Conservatory took to social media to speak about the bullying they endured during their training, breaking the taboo in the hushed world of classical ballet.

title: Michigan school shooter's parents sentenced to at least 10 years in prison
summary: Jennifer and James Crumbley are the first parents convicted in a US mass school shooting.

title: Euro 2025 qualifying: France secures decisive 1-0 win over Sweden
summary: Captain Wendie Renard's goal led Les Bleues to a win against Sweden in Gothenburg on Tuesday during their second qualifying match for the next continental tournament.

title: NBA hit by a tidal wave of sports betting
summary: Between betting irregularities and verbal abuse at venues and on social media, the North American basketball league has felt the first repercussions of the liberalization of sports betting in several US states.

title: What is celebrated on Eid-ul-Fitr (and why it is not to be confused with Eid-ul-Kebir)?
summary: On Wednesday, Muslims in France celebrate the end of the fasting practiced during the month of Ramadan.

title: Climate justice: Top European rights court condemns Switzerland in landmark ruling
summary: The European Court of Human Rights ruled on 3 cases filed by European citizens accusing countries of not doing enough to prevent climate change, rejecting two cases yet siding with one against Switzerland.

title: Palestinian writer Walid Daqqa dies in Israeli prison after 38 years of detention
summary: The body of the activist, who was suffering from cancer, is still being held by the Israeli authorities. Fifteen Palestinians have died in Israeli prisons since October 7, 2023.

title: In the Gaza Strip, war crimes are multiplying with the help of artificial intelligence
summary: Two investigations published in the Israeli press shed light on the army's operating methods, which utilizes algorithms and circumvents rules regarding the opening of fire.

title: Gambling in the Ukrainian army sparks controversy
summary: A commanding officer's petition denouncing the ravages of gambling addiction in the ranks of the military has been fuelling debate over regulating this booming sector.

title: Journalism and Crisis: Join Le Monde in English for a special event in New York!
summary: Le Monde's English edition crosses the Atlantic from April 15-17 for a series of events in New York City, free and open to the public.

title: Biden says Netanyahu making 'mistake' on Gaza
summary: In an interview aired on Tuesday, the US president said he didn't 'agree with his [Netanyahu's] approach' and urged Israel to call for a ceasefire.

title: Taiwan earthquake: Natural disaster expertise helped limit death toll
summary: Despite the powerful earthquake that shook the island's east coast on April 3, the death toll remained limited thanks to excellent natural disaster management.

title: Physicist Peter Higgs, father of the boson, has died
summary: In 2013, the British scientist was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics for having predicted as early as 1964 the existence of a particle finally discovered in 2012 at CERN.

title: Life suspended for a Gazan family in Cairo
summary: In November, Le Monde reported on the daily life of the war in Gaza through messages exchanged by photojournalist Sameh-Nidal Rahmi with a community of Arab photographers. Gabriel Ferneini went to meet him in Cairo after he left Gaza.

title: Landmark English review urges 'extreme caution' on youth gender identity healthcare
summary: The four-year investigation into services provided for young people dealing with gender identity issues comes weeks after puberty blockers were blocked for under-16s outside of research trials.

title: Women are the first victims of burnout
summary: From breakdown to rehabilitation, L'Burn, a Bordeaux-based organization, takes care of exhausted women from all over France. According to the country's public health body, more women than men are affected by work-related mental distress.

title: 'America needs more migrants'
summary: Rejection of immigration is likely to lead to serious economic difficulties, observes American economist Anne Krueger in her column.

title: What the French bill on end of life allows compared to its European neighbors
summary: Le Monde has listed the most frequent conditions that have led to euthanasia in Belgium and the Netherlands, and imagined the fate of the same patients in France if the draft law on 'aid in dying' were to be voted as it stands.

title: Russian who helped Ukrainians cross border dies in prison
summary: Beaten up during his arrest in the Belgorod region, the 61-year-old prisoner Alexander Demidenko had complained of torture.

title: When it comes to sex, do we set the bar too high?
summary: Media representations of sexuality create insane expectations which can only lead to disappointment in real life. It's time to change our frame of reference, writes columnist Maïa Mazaurette.

title: Climate change: Switzerland's condemnation by the ECHR marks 'historic' step
summary: For the first time, an international court has ruled on the harmful effects of climate change, establishing a direct link with quality of life, health and well-being.

title: London's Garrick Club may finally open its doors to women
summary: Under increasing pressure, one of the country's most powerful informal circles is considering accepting women. But will they want to join?

title: Germany denies 'facilitating genocide' in Gaza with its military aid to Israel
summary: Accused by Nicaragua in front of the International Court of Justice, Germany claims that the military equipment delivered to Israel is either defensive in nature or intended for training purposes.

title: 'This 'war economy' coined by Macron has yet to see the light of day'
summary: The French president's proactive strategic shift on Ukraine has raised hopes in Kyiv. What remains to be done is to provide the resources to match this commitment, writes columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.
